utterances: It does.
I mean, I do, you know, most of my friends - my musician friends - like ""A Day in the Life"" is sort of one of their favorite songs.
And I think that was my least favorite because, I think, it was creepy in a way that I didn't understand.
I didn't understand what was going on.
I mean, I felt I don't really understand what was going on, you know, that whole (unintelligible).
I'm not sure we we're meant to.
Yes, exactly, exactly.
It was all like kind of bringing nightmares in the house and trippy and - you know, I mean, it was musically super interesting.
But, like, I think for kids, it was like - it'd kind of creep me out for sure.
You also mentioned the other one, it's getting better all the time.
I used to get mad at my woman.
I beat her and kept her apart from the things that she likes.
What has his government said about this particular case of gender discrimination by the med school?

And it took them a long time to, you know, when you're a kid, you kind of, just like, you just belt along, you don't really pay attention, and then - you know, one day I was like, wait a minute, I beat her?
Like, that's seems a little…
That's (unintelligible) a little extreme.
Surely.
The Billy Shears I know, wouldn't have beat anyone, you know?
Yeah, it's - that was kind of a - I don't know.
But then you just like, well, you know, I guess it's getting better so…
I guess…
Maybe he didn't really be beat her.
Maybe it's just, you know, a figure of speech.
Yes.
And you also mentioned that, at some point, the magic of this record vanished or became too fragile for you to even look for it anymore?
You know, I think that it's - you hear songs, I mean, all Beatles songs, you hear them so much.
They're in commercials.
They're all over the place because, you know, people cover them.
It's really hard to, it's hard to get any distance and sort of maintain that, you know?
I mean, the magic of music is very fragile, like, you can't - you do wear it out.
It's like reading your favorite book over and over.
You kind of have to space it out.
And, you know, so I really am afraid to return to that.
But I (unintelligible) say, just like sharing a fragment of that record.
It's really, just like, there's excitement and it's varied, just the sonic quality.
It's very exciting, like, everything about it is exciting.
And I have a feeling if I really sat down and listen to it that, you know, that excitement would be brought back to me.
We're speaking today on the Opinion Page with Aimee Mann, whose op-ed on the Beatles' ""Sergeant Pepper's"" album, was in the New York Times on Sunday.
800-989-8255, if you'd like to join us 800-989-TALK, e-mail talk@npr.org.
We'll start with Mike, and Mike's with us from northeastern Oregon.
Good morning, Neal.
Hi.
You know, I'm listening really interestingly over the phone to Aimee's comments on ""Sergeant Pepper."" And I was, I am of age.
I'm actually 60, where the release of that album - I guess, 40 years ago - it seems like a light year or light years with a major event.
And I was in San Francisco, I returned there.
Actually, I was in Berkeley.
I was a student and then returned to Berkeley as a non-student, and I had a group of friends that were very much into music.
And they pulled an anticlimactic move on us in San Francisco.
One of the FM stations' bootleg, a few songs off of ""Sergeant Pepper's"" and played it in advance of the actual release.
But that didn't really dampen our enthusiasm a whole lot.
We were really, really looking forward to this record.
And so, we got together.
One of us bought - I don't know who had the money for it.
I can't remember which of us have the money to buy one.
But we did.
And we went to somebody's house.
We achieved alternate, alternative states of mind to listen to it.
A-ha.
And we sat around and played it over and over again for a long time.
And when was the moment when you realized, you know, hey, this whole thing hangs together pretty well?
I think - having heard bits and pieces of it earlier on the radio and then after listening to it several times - it was a grand work, I guess.

That's the best way to put it with an - it was truly an accomplishment because the Beatles were representative to a lot of people of, not just a couple of guys playing music, but of growth and change and the ability to become better at what you do and to express yourself better.
And they really, really, really, really did on that record.
And I - and that's - and although I don't think maybe if you break each song down individually, they all hold up.
I would certainly disagree with Aimee on ""A Day in the Life"".
That's just an absolute - that song itself, to me, I think, represents just absolute compassion for the human condition, and that's what I got out of it and still do.
But I - it's a wonderful, wonderful record, and it really did mean a lot to us at the time.
Mike, thanks very much.
You bet you.
Thank you.
There are, as we mentioned, it's the, the first real concept album like that, at least in rock 'n' roll, Aimee.
And, in a way, it's got a lot to answer for because every other rock 'n' roll group out there felt the need to come out with at least one more concept album.
Yes.
Some of which weren't quite as good.
Well, you know, it's a hard act to follow.
I mean, you know, it's like - that record really, really had it all.
And one of the things I think is interesting about ""Sergeant Pepper"" is that it was so, you know, kind of advanced and ahead of its time.
But it also, like, had so many elements of, like, older, you know, kind of dance hall.
Music hall stuff, yes.
Yeah, music halls stuff like.
Yeah, vaudeville kind of, you know, more old-fashioned elements.
And I think was the mixing of those, you know, modern and older elements that made it so interesting.
Let's get Mark on the line, Mark's with us from Portland.
Hi, Neal.
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
I should also say that welcome, Aimee Mann.
I saw her for about 10 years ago.
The local hall, they ever packed about, sold it out.
It was a great performance by any…
Oh, thank you.
…(unintelligible) Portland.
It's interesting to hear because of her age and different reflect on how it affected them by age, and I was about not quite 13 at that time.

And I had friends who were the hardest friends of mine that we could call ourselves at that age, but I (unintelligible) that they were influenced by my brother, I'm making mock cardboard guitars and lip-synching (unintelligible).

If this isn't a statement that life imitates art - which I think really became confirmed at this point without denial by many people that was later talked about 10 years that, of course, there has been so many great things said about the Beatles, like, almost hard to cover it again.
No, I'm just going down the list.
But that they were probably the first statement in music that was existentialist, I think someone said, for a generation at their time.
And, I guess, I'm sure anyone agree with this that there was, you know, it's a great impact on people.
Even at younger age, it's usually 8 years old.
Here's an 8-year-old that you, you said you didn't really understand who they were, that you mean…
No, really, I mean, I thought, you know, that it was a band called ""Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Heart Club"" band…
Well, I love the actual band.
Yes, I mean, I just didn't focused, I totally missed the fact that they were the Beatles and that the Beatles were the Beatles that I had heard, you know, a couple of years earlier…
They're somebody new then, I see.
Yes.
Yeah.
Or new or I didn't even - you know, to me, it was like music just do existed all on its own with no history and no contacts.
You know, I mean, I - because I didn't listen to the radio, and I was so young.
And, you know, I didn't have friends saying, like, oh, you got to hear this or you got to hear that.
I was, like, I was too young for that.
It was really just, you know, like a piece of music, kind of, out of nowhere.

And it's interesting because it's really that kind of, like, if a tree falls in the middle of the forest and, you know, like devoid of any Beatle mania or, you know, any of that kind of culture, you know?
I mean, like, of course, if something is super popular, you know, like people will listen to and be influenced by that.
But, you know, I mean just totally on its own thinking that it was like some band nobody else had heard of, you know?
I mean, I still, it's all about the music.
(Unintelligible).
She's older at the time when they first appeared in the ""Ed Sullivan Show,"" maybe…
Yeah.
…but that was an epic point in musical history.
